messageBody:
On Tuesday 18 April 2006 18:32, kotuv wrote:
> public void testCompressWithFileName(){
>
> boolean result = true;
> try{
> DataCompressionUtility.compress(smallFile);
> }catch(Exception ex){
> result = false;
> }
> Assert.assertTrue(result);
> }

And earlier, kotuv wrote:
> > Need to test a method that returns 'void'. Failure of the method is by
> > thorowing an exception. If no exception is thrown it is success.
> >
> > I have wrapped the method call in try...catch and placed
> > Assert.assertTrue(false) statement in the catch block. However even
> > when exception is thrown, this statement is not executed
> > and 'Succeful' message is output.
> >
> > Help appreciated.

I don't see why this test breaks in the way you describe, and I don't see
why your code is as complicated as you show for the test you want.
Isn't

DataCompressionUtility.compress(smallFile);

good enough? If it throws an exception, the test will fail. If it doesn't,
the test will pass. No booleans, try-catch blocks, or asserts required.

[Of course, it doesn't test that the compression is /right/, and I'd have
thought that a more important issue.]
